pros: Loved working here, loved the culture, loved the people
cons: A little disorganized kind of a start up vibe

pros: A flexible and immersive experience!
cons: No real cons to report.

pros: Good people who are mission driven.
cons: Toxic culture that regularly demonstrates a lack of respect or value for associates.

pros: Mission-orientated, nice grounds & amenitites
cons: Terrible culture, outdated leadership model & no trust.

pros: The work to support communities
cons: Two white women leading HR that have not grown with the times. Old school ways of doing things and managing people. Gatekeepers that only permit who they want

pros: Excellent work environment and great people.
cons: can’t think of anything negative

pros: Kauffman leadership is striving to be a better organization and do more good in our country. The leadership creates many opportunities to listen to staff from all levels and answer hard questions.
cons: As a foundation, sometimes there is too much autonomy and not enough accountability to what our mission and our impact could be. I am seeing that improve but there is work to do.

pros: * Benefits; PTO, 401(k), "opportunity" for personal and professional growth
cons:
* Salary
* Growth/Advancement opporutnities - lateral/flat
* Management
* Inconsistencies (Foundation level to team management level)
* Overworked and understaffed
* Work/life balance

pros: has a vision for tech
cons: the company needs more employees and funding

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: Excellent long-term career, benefits, flexibility, and work life balance— should your ego be checked at the front door
cons: Wavering messaging, lots of different initiatives and work... conflicts with priorities and measuring most impact life work

pros: Benefits are amazing, PTO and work life balance is the best I've ever had. Management genuinely cares about the employees and is constantly asking for feedback and trying to do and be the best they can.
cons: I do not have any cons.

review_title: Great resume builder if you can take the politics
pros:
I had the opportunity to work with some of the smartest, most innovative people that you will find. The Foundation, due in large part to its reputation, draws incredible talent. It is very energizing to work in an environment with literally some of the smartest people around. The benefits are also a big plus. The retirement is generous and heads above any other organization. If you can manage to survive at Kauffman for at least five years, and contribute all you can to your retirement, you will definitely see huge financial reward.

They are also very generous with time off and other meaningful rewards.
cons: The best way I can describe this is as such... Working at Kauffman is like being the children of very well off parents. You have the beautiful house, the finest education, and all the other things money can buy. Except your parents love and attention. Specifically, the culture is dismal. You can walk the halls of the Foundation and hear no laughter, no joyfulness. It is frankly depressing, which is a shame. Some of the hires at the Executive level four years ago were a train wreck that ultimately left the Entrepreneurship team a shell of its former self. So much interesting and impactful work was being done but once there was a leadership change all that changed. Bottom line is that this organization, despite it's stellar reputation and incredible benefits, has higher turnover than it should.

pros: Amazing benefits and compensation package.  Colleagues are brilliant, fun, and truly a pleasure to spend so much time with.  The work can be fast-paced and challenging, but the rewards and satisfaction outweigh any feelings of stress and pressure.  Very flexible with work/life balance.  I appreciate working with a predominantly female population, given the added sympathy towards parenting and deeper understanding of the demands that accompany having young children at home.  Your work team (and perhaps department) becomes like family, and there is a strong sense of caring among those that work the closest together.
cons: Some roles have been created in the not-so-distant past that don't make much sense, and don't seem to have a clear purpose.  Other roles were eliminated for reasons unknown, and were not replaced with logical alternatives.  New leadership has been brought on-board to better define and enhance the culture of the Foundation; what does that even mean? The Foundation has become somewhat of a clique-based atmosphere, and unless you're one of the "cool kids", you're not likely to be noticed or recognized for anything you do or any ideas you have.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work and share ideas - not so much anymore.
pros: It was wonderful being a part of the Kauffman Foundation. The work that is done and the legacy that it stems from makes working there a true honor. Being a part of something so iconic and impactful. With deep pockets, the idea of "money is no object and doesn't hinder us" is real, and allows the Foundation to support their employees with great benefits and work environment. Everything you need to do the job is given. Also the on-site cafe, on-site gym, 401k w/match, vacation, and holiday break are great.
cons: The Foundation, including management,  used to be full of amazing people who were passionate, intelligent, kind, listeners, hard workers, and just down to earth nice people who believed in the vision of Mr. K. Not so much anymore. The last management change seems to have been chosen for their ability to be managed/controlled. There was a time where you were listened to and encouraged to speak up, disagree, have a conversation and discuss differences; collaborate on the way forward. Now it's the opposite. Don't rock the boat.  Management places themselves on a pedestal and are unreachable. HR is now there for the employer, not the employee. Employees are afraid to disagree with management or speak up, and if you do - well - watch out.  The Board President is a woman, the CEO is a woman, and many key management positions are held by women, and yet they reduced maternity leave from 12 weeks paid to nearly nothing.

review_title: An amazing workplace with phenomenal benefits
pros:
-  Associate benefits are the best I've ever seen (including subsidized gourmet dining and onsite gym)
-  The senior leadership team is improving their communication with the associates, promoting inclusion
-  I'm able to do mission-based work in a community that I love while providing for my family
-  We are starting to embrace risk, change, and collaboration, which is so important to staying on-trend in today's entrepreneurial/educational environment
cons:
-  Senior leaders can sometimes feel "untouchable" which discourages some associates from interacting with them.  Getting better but it's still there in some instances
-  Because of the myriad of benefits, associates tend to get a bit entitled and vocal with their displeasure of not having/receiving "more"
-  Same stuff you'll see in other workplaces

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: One of largest foundations in the United Sates. Committed to promoting entrepreneurship and small business. The foundation enjoyed a ten year run as a respected leader in promoting entrepreneurship and published idea books like "Rules for Growth."
cons: Insular local focus with management change in past two years. Benno Schmidt was an effective leader with an extraordinary global vision and business background.  The former chairman engineered an amazing restructuring of the trustees with local friends and supporters and then was appointed CEO of the organization.  He has a narrow local focus. Once interested in demonstrating scalability of ideas, they now operate non-replicable projects like the Kauffman School -- a notable effort with millions of dollars of real estate and facility investment that no independent source could copy to fix urban education.

review_title: They supported my work at a critical moment!
pros:
Not a former employee but someone who Kauffman funded and who has been giving friendly advice for years. 

Kauffman walks the walk - when something intrigues them, they support it. I was so pleased that they backed Startup Weekend and continue to back Global Entrepreneurship Week, Ice House, FastTrac, etc. 

I would, however, love to find ways to help them - even as employee or fellow or ??
cons: Again, not a former employee - my only concern has been that they seem to only take research seriously if it's done by economists :)

review_title: Make an Impact with Your Work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros:
As the title says, working at the Foundation gives you an opportunity to have a real impact with your work. You have the opportunity to build something that ultimately solves a problem in our communities and that powerful driver has brought a group of committed, creative and intelligent professionals to the Foundation. 

Additionally, the Foundation values employees and offers great benefits, flexibility, personal and professional development, among other things.
cons: The Foundation still struggles with the the same business challenges that other companies do, no matter how great the work is. e.g. processes, technology implementation, communication, de-siloing etc.

pros: The organization has an important mission:  to promote education and entrepreneurship through charitable giving.  Employees are referred to as "associates" in honor of Mr. Kauffman who felt that people who worked with him were more than "employees."  Associates receive very generous benefits packages and a two week holiday vacation.
cons: Currently, the organization struggles with significant leadership changes.  The last three years have seen three different CEOs, and many in the organization desire a strong vision.

review_title: Great place.  Cannot think of a better one
pros: Great people, flexibility and creativity in your job + organizational mission, and visible impact.  You can propose what you want.  If it's good, people will say "OK, why don't you do it?"
cons: Undefined mission and emerging priorities, which can be great because we're working on innovation and entrepreneurship that change/evolve all the time.  But it may not be a place if you need to sit and work on the same thing for 3-5 years.  There was some shift in the highest management for the last 2 years, but the new management should last a while.

pros: It used to be a place where a person with at least one outstanding skill can be hired and  fully demonstrate your skills with passion.  If you didn't fit with your supervisor, you could be transitioned to another division because people  saw it and were sympathetic.
cons: Now it's all about fit.  Sadly, it's not about organizational fit, but personal fit with your supervisor.  It gets worse if your supervisor cannot show a vision, but only expects verbal massage.  Those people are now CEO and a couple of VPs there, and it will be very frustrating if you cannot show your skill or passion.

review_title: Smart, passionate people who are constantly looking to learn and grow
pros:
Colleagues who are passionate about improving educational outcomes for kids, increasing rates of entrepreneurship (especially for underserved populations), and improving the lives of folks in Kansas City.
Incredibly friendly culture where folks go out of their way to help others.
Strong commitment to the values of Mr K: excellence, humility, respect, stewardship, humor
Huge potential for positive impact on the community
cons: The onsite gym is kinda small :)

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great work/life balance and retirement/PTO benefits
cons: No opportunity to advance, no mentorship and poor leadership in Finance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great mission. Very well resourced. There are a few great, very genuine people. Good benefits and compensation. Really great work/life balance. Very nice facilities.
cons: Political culture stratified by length of service. There is a real thread of entitlement running through the culture. On paper the Foundation is chasing great values but it's not getting through to everybody.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros:
-Unbelievable benefits - good pay, loads of time off, flexibility in schedule to accommodate needs

-Strong and growing culture - EMKF is finding itself and the organization does an excellent job to create a good community internally through lots of team interaction

-Professional support - In whatever way you'd like to grow yourself professionally, just know that you'll find the support for that here
cons: Like many philanthropies, it's highly visible work in the community/nationally, so it has a bit higher pressure than other work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: The mission is great. If your idea is accepted, they have (financial) resources to make it happen. Some smart people.
cons: Unfortunately, the turmoil of leadership and board in the last several years has span the organization down. Divisional strategic plans are prioritized, while the organization as a whole has neither strategy nor goal.  Culture is emphasized, but the leaders don't listen to different ideas and laid off more than a dozen people in the last two years.

pros: Flexible people and great mentors that really allow you to build your work capacity and bandwidth for quality. The work is extreamly interesting for people coming from areas in Finance, Accounting, Economics, Marketing, Human Resources, Development studies and research.
cons: There's always room for higher salaries, almost everywhere in the world and Kauffman would definitely be better off with more delicious salary structures probably.

review_title: Friendly place, but a lot of bureaucracy
job_title: Senior Analyst in Kansas City, MO
pros: Beautiful offices, nice people, great pay and a wonderful mission.
cons: Initiatives move at a snail's pace, oftentimes because people aren't willing to make decisions and execute on them.  Simple things like paying bills and submitting grant proposals take so. much. longer. than they have any reason to. Very few advancement opportunities due to the small nature of the company and relatively young (Gen X) senior management.

pros: Benefits both medical and retirement
cons: When the new president was decided a few years ago, she laid off more than half of VPs.  When a new VP came, he laid off close to half of people.  It's been a few years now, and I thought things are finally settling, but a VP is leaving (or forced to leave) now.  You don't have to be smart to figure out that another round of layoff is waiting here.  The leadership here doesn't have a clue about what is needed to run an organization.

pros: Pay is not so bad.
cons: I thought the organization had some good reputation, but the name and reality don't match? The senior management has no strategy, but only personal likes and dislikes. The rest of people kinda keep saying like "we're a great foundation because people say good things about us." Of course, people say good things because we give money., and no other reason needed. We need to graduate from this, and got to do something other than following legacy and reputation.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, KS
pros: Great people, excellent culture, strong focus on professional development and advancement for staff. The work environment here is outstanding in every respect.
cons: The foundation has gone through a transition period and is still settling into a new structure and operating approach.

pros:
This was a great summer experience.
Paid travel to conferences
Salary good, commensurate with experience
I had a good supervisor, don't know what the other interns in the other departments thought of theirs
cons: could have helped if we worked on more grown up research, instead of doing simple literature reviews

pros: Great place to work.  Amazing benefits and some wonderful people to work with.
cons: Leadership.  There have been three CEOs in the past few years and the board can't seem to decide whether to be a national foundation of some great significance or whether just to shovel money at local projects.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: This is an amazing place to work. Great people, great mission, great values and lots of perks. It was such a pleasure to come to work every day and try to change the world!
cons: Its really hard to think of any...

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Legacy: Mr. Kauffman's and the previous leaders'
cons: The current leadership does not propose any vision, except to be uncommon (which has no direction), but accept the strategy imposed by external consultants and divided by divisions.  Talking about culture and periodically laying off (especially good people) never work together, but they are even unaware of it.  Now the focus is to satisfy local stakeholders, which will bring them down from national to local foundation.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: They used to have some great things and people.
cons: I decided to leave because they laid off a number of most talented people for no comprehensible strategic reason, and they did not even communicate well.  Then, they talk about building culture. It's simply impossible.

review_title: Organization with an Amazing Vision and Heart
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO

There are many opportunities for engaging and satisfying work, despite being a "flat" organization.

Colleagues who are smart, emotionally intelligent and fun.
cons: Can be very demanding and challenging--which is stressful at times, yet also satisfying.

CEO is dedicated and approachable
